title: How to Get Health Insurance in Switzerland
subtitle: Mandatory basic insurance for everyone
bodyMarkdown:
# Health Insurance in Switzerland

Health insurance is mandatory in Switzerland. Within 3 months of registration, you must choose an insurance company and sign up for basic coverage (Grundversicherung).

> Important: Insurance is effective from your canton registration date, even if you sign up later. Delays can lead to back payments and penalties.

---

## What Basic Insurance Covers
- Family doctor and specialist visits (with referral)
- Medications from the official list, physiotherapy, lab tests
- Hospital stays (within your canton), emergency care
- Pregnancy, childbirth, emergency dental care

## Insurance Models
- [ ] **Standard** — free choice of doctor, more expensive
- [ ] **HMO** — through family practice, cheaper
- [ ] **Telmed** — phone/online consultation first, cheaper
- [ ] **Hausarztmodell** — tied to family doctor

> Tip: HMO and Telmed are usually 10–20% cheaper. Great if you rarely visit doctors.

## Deductible and Co-payment
- **Franchise (deductible)** — annual amount (300–2500 CHF). Higher deductible = lower monthly premium.
- **Selbstbehalt (co-payment)** — 10% of costs after reaching deductible (max 700 CHF/year for adults).

### Example Calculation
- Deductible 300 CHF, you paid 500 CHF for medications. You pay 300 CHF deductible + 10% of remaining 200 CHF = 20 CHF. Total 320 CHF.
- If deductible is 2500 CHF and you spent 500 CHF — you pay all 500 CHF yourself.

---

## How to Choose Insurance (Step by Step)
1. Compare prices and models on **comparis.ch** or **bonus.ch**
2. Choose a deductible based on your risk profile (if healthy — can be higher)
3. Check discounts for alternative models (HMO/Telmed)
4. Verify service language and partner clinics
5. Apply online or in person. Policy and card will arrive by mail.
6. Keep all treatment payment receipts!

## Subsidies (Prämienverbilligung)
If your income is below the threshold, apply to the cantonal service (Sozialamt/AHV). Each canton has its own deadline and portal.

### Documents for Subsidy
- Income statement
- Copy of policy
- Residence permit (Ausweis S)
- Certificate from Gemeinde

> Important: Apply immediately after getting insurance. Subsidies are not retroactive!

---

## Useful Terms
- **Hausarzt** — family doctor
- **Notfall** — emergency
- **Apotheke** — pharmacy
- **Arzneimittelliste** — list of reimbursable medications
- **Krankenkasse** — health insurance company

## Emergency Numbers
- **144** — ambulance
- **143** — psychological support (anonymous)
- **117** — police
- **118** — fire department

### Common Mistakes
- Chose too high a deductible — large payments when visiting doctors
- Missed the 3-month deadline — possible back payments
- Didn't apply for subsidy on time
- Didn't keep treatment payment receipts

---

## Additional Insurance (Optional)
- **Dental** — basic insurance doesn't cover regular dental treatment
- **Vision** — contacts and glasses aren't covered either
- **Semi-private/private room** — for more comfortable hospital stays
- **Alternative medicine** — homeopathy, acupuncture

> Tip: Additional insurance is more expensive. Evaluate if you really need it.

title: Gemeinde Registration: Step-by-Step Guide
subtitle: Anmeldung — mandatory residence registration
bodyMarkdown:
# Gemeinde Registration (Anmeldung)

After arriving in Switzerland, you must register with the local administration (Gemeinde) at your residence within **14 days**.

> Warning: Late registration can result in a fine!

---

## What You Need for Registration

### Required Documents
- [ ] Passport or ID of all family members
- [ ] Rental contract (Mietvertrag) or proof of residence
- [ ] Residence permit (Ausweis S or other)
- [ ] Photo (sometimes required, check in advance)

### Additional Documents (may be needed)
- Children's birth certificates
- Marriage/divorce certificate
- Previous address (if moving within Switzerland)

---

## How to Register (Step by Step)

### Step 1: Find Your Gemeinde
Each city/village has its own administration. Find the address:
- On the canton's official website
- Via Google Maps: "Gemeinde [your city]"
- Ask your landlord

### Step 2: Check Office Hours
Many Gemeinde only work certain hours (e.g., Tue/Thu 2:00–5:00 PM). Some require an appointment (Termin).

> Tip: Call ahead or check the website to avoid a wasted trip.

### Step 3: Visit the Gemeinde
On site:
1. Fill out the Anmeldung form (registration form)
2. Submit copies of documents
3. Receive registration confirmation (Anmeldebestätigung)

### Step 4: What's Next
After registration:
- You'll receive official address confirmation
- This is needed for opening a bank account, insurance, school
- Gemeinde forwards data to cantonal services (Migrationsamt)

---

## Important Terms
- **Anmeldung** — registration
- **Abmeldung** — deregistration (when moving out)
- **Wohnsitz** — place of residence
- **Einwohnermeldeamt** — resident registration office

---

## FAQ

### Is there a registration fee?
Most Gemeinde have free registration. Some may charge a small fee (5–20 CHF).

### What if I don't speak German/French?
Many Gemeinde have English-speaking staff. If not — bring a friend as translator or use Google Translate.

### Do I need to register again when moving?
Yes! If you move to another city/canton, you must:
1. Deregister (Abmeldung) at the old Gemeinde
2. Register (Anmeldung) at the new Gemeinde within 14 days

---

## Useful Links
- **ch.ch** — official portal of Switzerland (English/German/French)
- Your canton's website (e.g., zh.ch for Zurich)
- Your Gemeinde's website

> Tip: Keep your Anmeldebestätigung — you'll need it many times!

title: Job Search in Switzerland: Getting Started
subtitle: Job portals, RAV/ORP and diploma recognition
bodyMarkdown:
# Job Search in Switzerland

Switzerland is one of the world's wealthiest countries with high salaries, but competition is also high. If you have an S permit, you can work without additional permits.

> Important: The S permit allows working throughout Switzerland.

---

## Main Job Search Portals

### Top 5 Sites
1. **jobs.ch** — largest job portal
2. **jobup.ch** — popular in French-speaking cantons
3. **indeed.ch** — international aggregator
4. **linkedin.com** — for professionals and networking
5. **job-room.ch** — official RAV portal (state employment service)

### Specialized Portals
- **hotel-jobs.ch** — hotels and restaurants
- **bau-stellen.ch** — construction
- **gastrojobs.com** — gastronomy
- **jobagent.ch** — IT and engineering

---

## Creating a Swiss-Style CV

### CV Structure
1. **Personal Data**: name, address, phone, email, date of birth
2. **Photo** (preferably professional, light background)
3. **Work Experience** (reverse chronological — most recent first)
4. **Education** (university, college, courses)
5. **Skills**: languages (indicate level A1–C2), IT, soft skills
6. **Hobbies** (optional, but Swiss like to see this)

### Format
- **Length**: 1–2 pages (max 3 for experienced professionals)
- **Language**: German/French/English (depending on region)
- **File format**: PDF

> Tip: Use templates from **cvmaker.ch** or **europass**.

---

## Cover Letter (Motivationsschreiben)

In Switzerland, the cover letter is very important! Don't copy templates — write specifically for each position.

### Structure
1. **Header**: "Bewerbung als [position]"
2. **Introduction**: why you're interested in this company
3. **Main part**: your experience and skills matching requirements
4. **Conclusion**: when you can start, contacts

---

## Diploma Recognition

If you have higher education from Ukraine, it needs to be recognized:

### For Regulated Professions (doctor, teacher, lawyer)
Contact **SBFI** (State Secretariat for Education):
- sbfi.admin.ch → Recognition of foreign qualifications
- Submit documents online
- Processing time: 2–6 months
- Additional exams may be required

### For Unregulated Professions (IT, business, engineering)
Recognition is not mandatory, but helpful:
- Helps employer understand your level
- Increases acceptance chances

---

## RAV/ORP — Government Assistance

If you haven't found work for several months, contact **RAV** (Regionales Arbeitsvermittlungszentrum) or **ORP** (Office régional de placement).

### What They Offer
- Career counseling
- CV assistance
- Referrals to retraining courses
- Financial support (under certain conditions)

> Important: To receive unemployment benefits, you need to have worked at least 12 months in Switzerland. With an S permit, conditions may differ.

---

## Minimum Wage and Conditions

Switzerland has no federal minimum wage, but:
- Most cantons have set a minimum of 3000–4500 CHF/month (gross)
- Average salary: 6000–8000 CHF/month
- IT/finance/medicine: 8000–15,000 CHF/month

### Standard Working Hours
- 40–42 hours/week
- Minimum 4 weeks vacation/year (5 weeks for employees under 20)

---

## Useful Terms
- **Bewerbung** — job application
- **Vorstellungsgespräch** — interview
- **Arbeitsvertrag** — employment contract
- **Bruttolohn** — gross salary
- **Nettolohn** — net salary

> Tip: Before the interview, learn about the company and prepare questions — it makes a good impression!

title: Finding an Apartment in Switzerland: Complete Guide
subtitle: Homegate, ImmoScout24, how to prepare documents and successfully rent
bodyMarkdown:
# Finding an Apartment in Switzerland

The rental market in Switzerland is very competitive, especially in major cities (Zurich, Geneva, Basel, Bern). One apartment can receive 50–200 applications. That's why it's important to prepare a complete document package and act quickly.

> Important: In Switzerland, 90% of housing is rented. Buying an apartment is rare even for locals.

---

## Where to Search for an Apartment

### Top 5 Platforms

1. **homegate.ch** — largest real estate portal
   - 80% of all listings
   - Filters by price, location, area
   - New listing alerts
   - Mobile app

2. **immoscout24.ch** — popular alternative
   - Convenient interface
   - Detailed maps and photos
   - Virtual tours

3. **tutti.ch** — classifieds (often cheaper options)
   - Direct rental from owners
   - Less competition
   - Shared housing (WG)

4. **wgzimmer.ch** — shared housing (WG)
   - Rooms in apartments
   - 30–50% cheaper
   - Social adaptation

5. **Facebook groups** — local groups
   - "Wohnung Zürich", "Housing Geneva", etc.
   - Quick listings
   - Direct contact with landlords

---

## Rental Costs (Approximate)

### Zurich (ZH)
- 1 room: 1200–1800 CHF/month
- 2 rooms: 1600–2500 CHF/month
- 3 rooms: 2200–3500 CHF/month
- WG room: 600–1000 CHF/month

### Geneva (GE)
- 1 room: 1100–1700 CHF/month
- 2 rooms: 1500–2300 CHF/month
- 3 rooms: 2000–3200 CHF/month

### Bern (BE)
- 1 room: 900–1400 CHF/month
- 2 rooms: 1200–1900 CHF/month
- 3 rooms: 1600–2500 CHF/month

> Tip: Nebenkosten (utilities) usually add 150–300 CHF/month (heating, water, common area cleaning).

---

## Document Package for Application

### Required Documents
- [ ] **Bewerbungsformular** — applicant form (provided by landlord or agent)
- [ ] **Passport/ID** — copy
- [ ] **Residence permit** (Ausweis S/B/C)
- [ ] **Employment contract** (Arbeitsvertrag) or income proof
- [ ] **Last 3 payslips**
- [ ] **Betreibungsregisterauszug** — debt-free extract (can be ordered online for 20 CHF)
- [ ] **Cover letter** (Motivationsschreiben) — why you?

### Additional Documents (upon request)
- Reference from previous landlord
- Bank statement showing financial capability
- Insurance policy copy (Haftpflichtversicherung)

> Important: Prepare all documents in advance as PDFs. Speed is key to success!

---

## Viewing the Apartment (Besichtigung)

### How to Prepare
- [ ] Arrive 5–10 minutes early
- [ ] Dress neatly (Business Casual)
- [ ] Bring notepad for notes
- [ ] Prepare questions in advance
- [ ] Bring your document package (just in case)

### What to Check During Viewing
- Condition of windows, doors, floors
- Heating (does it work?)
- Water (hot/cold)
- Electricity (enough outlets?)
- Noise (street, neighbors)
- Basement/storage (is there storage space?)
- Laundry (in building or private?)

---

## Mietkaution (Deposit)

### How It Works
- **Amount**: 2–3 monthly rent payments (excluding Nebenkosten)
- **Where it's kept**: in a **blocked account** (gesperrtes Konto) at your bank
- **Interest**: accrues to you
- **Return**: after move-out (minus any damages)

> Important: Never give deposit in cash! Only through bank.

---

## Rental Agreement (Mietvertrag)

### What to Check Before Signing
- [ ] **Monthly rent** (Mietzins) — exact amount
- [ ] **Nebenkosten** (utilities) — how much and what's included
- [ ] **Kündigungsfrist** (notice period) — usually 3 months
- [ ] **Kündigungstermine** (termination dates) — usually end of month or quarter
- [ ] **Übernahmeprotokoll** (handover protocol) — apartment condition at move-in
- [ ] **Hausordnung** (house rules) — quiet after 10 PM, laundry, trash

> Tip: Ask a friend or lawyer to review the contract before signing.

title: Enrolling Your Child in School in Switzerland
subtitle: Complete guide to compulsory education (4–15 years)
bodyMarkdown:
# Enrolling Your Child in School in Switzerland

Education in Switzerland is compulsory for all children aged 4–6 years (depending on canton) to 15 years. The education system is free and high-quality.

> Important: You need to enroll your child in school immediately after registering at Gemeinde. School is automatically assigned based on residence.

---

## Education System in Switzerland

### Kindergarten / Vorschule (4–6 years)
- **2 years of preschool** — learning through play
- Language: German, French, or Italian (depending on region)
- Free
- Mandatory in most cantons (from age 4)

### Primarschule (6–12 years)
- **6 years of primary school**
- Core subjects: math, languages, science, sports
- Small classes (15–20 students)
- Free

### Sekundarstufe I (12–15 years)
- **3 years of secondary school** (mandatory)
- Division by levels (A/B/C or Gymnasium/Realschule/Sekundarschule)
- Preparation for vocational or academic education

---

## How to Enroll: Step-by-Step

### Step 1: Register at Gemeinde
After registering at your residence, Gemeinde automatically forwards data to **Schulamt** (school administration).

### Step 2: Wait for Letter from Schulamt
Within 2–4 weeks you'll receive:
- Name of assigned school
- Start date
- List of required documents

### Step 3: Visit the School
Visit the school in person to:
- Meet the teacher and principal
- Tour the school
- Discuss child's special needs (language, health)

### Step 4: Submit Documents
- [ ] Child's passport/ID
- [ ] Birth certificate
- [ ] Anmeldebestätigung (registration confirmation)
- [ ] Vaccination card (Impfausweis) — recommended
- [ ] Previous school documents (if any)

> Tip: If the child doesn't know German/French, many schools offer free preparatory classes (Deutschkurs für Kinder, Classe d'accueil).

---

## Language Support for Refugee Children

### Integration Classes (Integrationsklasse / Willkommensklasse)
Many cantons offer **special preparatory classes** for migrant children:
- Intensive language learning (6–12 months)
- Adaptation to Swiss system
- Then transition to regular class

---

## Daycare (Kita) for Toddlers (0–4 years)

### When Kita is Needed
- Both parents work
- Single parent
- Child's social integration

### Cost
Kita is **paid**, but:
- Subventionierte Kita Plätze — subsidized places for low-income families
- Price: 50–150 CHF/day (depends on income)
- Apply through Sozialamt or Kita office of your Gemeinde

> Important: Kita waiting lists can be long (3–6 months). Apply immediately!

---

## Useful Terms
- **Schulamt** — school administration
- **Kindergarten** — preschool (4–6 years)
- **Primarschule** — primary school (6–12)
- **Sekundarschule** — secondary school (12–15)
- **Kita** — daycare (0–4)
- **Impfausweis** — vaccination card
- **Schulmaterial** — school supplies
- **Elternabend** — parent-teacher meeting

title: Travel Passes and Transport in Switzerland
subtitle: GA, Halbtax, ZVV — how to save on transport
bodyMarkdown:
# Transport in Switzerland: Complete Guide

Switzerland has one of the best transport systems in the world. Trains, buses, trams and boats run exactly on schedule and cover the entire country.

> Important: Traveling without a ticket is fined 90–120 CHF. Always buy a ticket before boarding!

---

## Types of Tickets and Passes

### 1. Single Ticket (Einzelbillet)
- Purchased for a specific trip
- Valid for all transport types within zone
- Price: 2.80–20 CHF (depending on distance)
- Where to buy: SBB machine, SBB Mobile app, online

### 2. Halbtax (50% Discount)
- **Cost**: 185 CHF/year (students 120 CHF/year)
- **What it gives**: 50% discount on all tickets (trains, buses, mountain lifts)
- **When worthwhile**: if you spend >370 CHF/year on transport

> Tip: Halbtax pays for itself in 2–3 intercity trips!

### 3. GA (Generalabonnement) — Unlimited Travel
- **Cost**: 3995 CHF/year (2nd class) or 6300 CHF/year (1st class)
- **What it gives**: unlimited travel on all transport types (SBB, PostAuto, trams, boats, most mountain lifts)
- **When worthwhile**: if you travel daily or extensively

### 4. Regional Passes (ZVV, Unia, Libero, etc.)
- **ZVV** (Zurich): 85–180 CHF/month (depending on zones)
- **Unia** (Bern): 70–150 CHF/month
- **Libero** (Basel): 60–140 CHF/month
- **What they give**: unlimited travel within certain zones

---

## How to Buy a Ticket

### Method 1: SBB Mobile App (Recommended)
1. Download **SBB Mobile** (free)
2. Select route and ticket type
3. Pay by card or Apple/Google Pay
4. Ticket activates automatically

> Tip: You can buy a ticket on the train via the app without extra charge!

### Method 2: Machine at Station
- Select language (DE/FR/IT/EN)
- Enter destination
- Select ticket type (single/return)
- Pay cash or card

### Method 3: Counter at Major Stations
- Open 6:00–9:00 PM (until 10:00 PM at major stations)
- Cash or card payment
- Can buy Halbtax or GA

---

## Discounts for Refugees and Low-Income

### Social Discounts (Sozialtarif)
Some cantons offer **discounts on passes** for people receiving social assistance:
- Zurich: ZVV for 50 CHF/month (instead of 85 CHF)
- Bern: Unia for 40 CHF/month
- Geneva: Unireso for 30 CHF/month

**How to get**: contact Sozialamt or Gemeinde with income proof.

---

## Transport Usage Rules

### What You Need to Know
- [ ] **Always have ticket** — inspectors don't warn
- [ ] **No validation needed** — ticket is active immediately after purchase
- [ ] **1st/2nd class** — check car class (1st more expensive but more comfortable)
- [ ] **Bicycles** — need separate ticket (12–18 CHF)
- [ ] **Dogs** — large dogs need ticket (50% of adult fare)

### Fines
- **No ticket**: 90–120 CHF + ticket cost
- **Wrong class ticket**: 60 CHF + price difference
- **Bike without ticket**: 60 CHF

---

## Useful Terms
- **Gleis** — platform
- **Ankunft** — arrival
- **Abfahrt** — departure
- **Verspätung** — delay
- **Umsteigen** — transfer
- **Billettautomat** — ticket machine
- **Kontrolle** — ticket inspection

---

## Useful Links
- **SBB**: sbb.ch — schedules and tickets for all of Switzerland
- **ZVV** (Zurich): zvv.ch
- **TPG** (Geneva): tpg.ch
- **BVB** (Basel): bvb.ch

> Tip: Download SBB Mobile and register Halbtax — it's the easiest way to use transport!
